section.name: Benchmark
section.p: The table below contains the output of the benchmark.xml ant script. To execute the script call this from a console:
Below is a description of all the pairing parameters used for the tests. In each case the curve group has a 160-bit group order, and k denotes the embedding degree of the curve.

tr.td: Good for cryptosystems where group element size is not critical. Uses supersingular curve Y^2 = X^3 + X. Group order is a Solinas prime.
Good for cryptosystems when group elements must be as short as possible. Uses MNT method to generate curves.
Not useful, but requires only modular arithmetic to implement. Curve easily found using CM method.
Useful for insuring against future finite field discrete log algorithm improvements. Curve found using method due to Paulo Barreto.
Slower than embedding degree 12 pairings, perhaps not worth using. Uses Freeman-Scott algorithm to generate curves.

Some cryptosystems need the curve order to be a specific number, e.g. N= p q where p and q are large primes so that N is hard to factorize. We can find a suitable pairing by using the same curve as for type A pairings.

section.p: We have executed the benchmark on different testbeds. Have look below.

ol.li: TestBed 1: Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Quad CPU Q6600 @ 2.40GHz, 3 GB Ram, Ubuntu 9.10
TestBed 2: Intel(R) Pentium 4 @ 2.00GHz, 1 GB Ram, Windows XP (Service Pack 3)

subsection.name: Machine Configuration
